{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{good article}} {{speciesbox | fossil_range = {{fossil range|3.6|0|[[Aquitanian (stage)|Aquitanian]] – Recent}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Atractosteus spatula (Bernard Germain de Lacépède) |url=https://paleobiodb.org/classic/checkTaxonInfo?taxon_name=Atractosteus+spatula&is_real_user=1 |website=Paleontological database}}</ref> | name = Alligator gar | image = Alligator Gar 10.JPG | image_caption = Alligator gar in an aquarium | genus = Atractosteus | species = spatula | authority = ([[Bernard Germain Étienne comte de La Ville-sur-Illon La Cépède|Lacépède]], 1803) | synonyms = {{collapsible list|bullets = true|title=<small>Species</small> | ''Lepisosteus spatula'' <small>Lacépède 1803</small> | ''Esox cepedianus'' <small>Shaw 1804</small> | ''Litholepis adamantinus'' <small>[[Constantine Samuel Rafinesque-Schmaltz|Rafinesque]] 1818</small> | ''Atractosteus adamantinus'' <small>([[Constantine Samuel Rafinesque-Schmaltz|Rafinesque]] 1818)</small> | ''Lepisosteus ferox'' <small>[[Constantine Samuel Rafinesque-Schmaltz|Rafinesque]] 1820</small> | ''Atractosteus ferox'' <small>(Rafinesque 1820)</small> | ''Lepidosteus chasei'' <small>Wailes 1854</small> | ''Lepisosteus berlandieri'' <small>Girard 1858</small> | ''Atractosteus lucius'' <small>Duméril 1870</small> }} | synonyms_ref=<ref>{{Cite website|last=Froese|first=R.|last2=Pauly|first2=D.|year=2017|title=Lepisosteidae |url=http://www.fishbase.se/Summary/FamilySummary.php?ID=34|website=[[FishBase]] version (02/2017)|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> | range_map = Alligator gar-range-Atractosteus spatula.png }} The '''alligator gar''' (''Atractosteus spatula'') is a [[ray-finned]] [[euryhaline]] fish related to the [[bowfin]] in the [[infraclass]] [[Holostei]] {{IPAc-en|h|oʊ|ˈ|l|ɒ|s|t|i|ai}}. It is the largest species in the [[gar]] family, and among the largest freshwater fishes in [[North America]]. The [[fossil record]] traces its existence back to the [[Early Cretaceous]] over a hundred million years ago.
Gars are often referred to as "[[primitive fishes]]", or "[[living fossils]]" because they have retained some [[Morphological (biology)|morphological]] characteristics of their earliest ancestors, such as a [[spiral valve]] intestine which is also common to the digestive system of [[sharks]], and the ability to breathe both air and water. Their common name was derived from their resemblance to the American [[alligator]], particularly their broad snout and long, sharp teeth. [[Anecdotal evidence]] in several scientific reports suggest that an alligator gar can grow up to {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} in length, but in 2011, the largest alligator gar ever caught and officially recorded was {{Convert|8|ft|5+1/4|in|abbr=on}} long, weighed {{Convert|327|lb|abbr=on}}, and was {{Convert|47|in|cm|abbr=on}} around the girth.
The body of an alligator gar is torpedo-shaped, usually brown or olive fading to a lighter gray or yellow [[ventral]] surface. Their scales are not like the scales of other fishes; rather, they are [[ganoid scale]]s which are bone-like, diamond-shaped scales, often with serrated edges, and covered by an enamel-like substance. Ganoid scales are nearly impenetrable and are excellent protection against predation. Unlike other gar species, the upper jaw of an alligator gar has a dual row of large, sharp teeth which are used to impale and hold prey. Alligator gar are stalking, ambush [[Predation|predators]], primarily [[piscivores]], but they will also ambush and eat [[water fowl]] and small [[mammal]]s they find floating on the water's surface.
Populations of alligator gar have been [[Local extinction|extirpated]] from much of their historic range as a result of habitat destruction, indiscriminate [[culling]], and unrestricted harvests. Populations are now located primarily in the southern portions of the [[United States]] extending into [[Mexico]]. They are considered [[euryhaline]] because they can adapt to varying salinities ranging from [[freshwater lake]]s and [[swamp]]s to [[brackish marsh]]es, [[estuary|estuaries]], and [[bay]]s along the [[Gulf of Mexico]].
For nearly a half-century, alligator gar were considered "trash fish",<ref name=FWS>{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/natchitoches/Newsletters/August%20%202013.pdf|publisher=US Fish & Wildlife Service|title=Fleur De Lis Fisheries|author =Brady, Tony |page=2|date=August 2013}}</ref> or a "nuisance species" detrimental to [[sportfish|sport fisheries]], so were targeted for elimination by state and federal authorities in the United States. The 1980s brought a better understanding of the ecological balance necessary to sustain an ecosystem,<ref name="Milbrath">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Oe6mPrxnvdIC&pg=PA271 | title=Envisioning a Sustainable Society: Learning Our Way Out | publisher=SUNY Press | author=Milbrath, Lester W. | year=1989 | page=271 | isbn=9780791401620}}</ref> and eventually an awareness that alligator gar were no less important than any other living organism in the [[ecosystem]]s they inhabit.<ref name="WarmSpringsNFH">{{cite web | url=http://www.fws.gov/warmsprings/fishhatchery/species/alligatorgar.html | title=Alligator Gar, Atractosteus spatula | publisher=US Fish & Wildlife Service | work=Warm Springs National Fish Hatchery | date=February 5, 2013 | accessdate=July 7, 2014 | author=Echevarria, Carlos}}</ref> Over time, alligator gar were afforded some protection by state and federal resource agencies. They are also protected under the [[Lacey Act]] which makes it illegal to transport certain species of fish in [[interstate commerce]] when in violation of [[state law]] or regulation. Several state and federal resource agencies are monitoring populations in the wild, and have initiated outreach programs to educate the public. Alligator gar are being [[aquaculture|cultured]] in ponds, pools, [[Raceway (aquaculture)|raceways]], and tanks by federal [[hatchery|hatcheries]] for mitigation stocking, by universities for research purposes, and in Mexico for consumption.<ref name="UAEX">{{cite web | url=http://aqfi.uaex.edu/people/faculty/slochmann/pages/New-Research/Default.htm | title=New Research | publisher=University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff | work=Aquaculture and Fisheries Center | accessdate=June 18, 2014 |author1=Lochmann, S.E. |author2=Baker, Brandon W. |author3=Rachels, Kyle T. |author4=Timmons, Brett A. }}</ref>
==Anatomy== [[File:GarGillCU.jpg|thumb|Gill of a juvenile gar]] [[File:Showing dual rows of teeth.jpeg|thumb|Preserved display of an alligator gar head]] [[File:Alligator gar grabs prey.webmhd.webm|thumb|180px|Alligator gar are stalking, ambush predators.|right]] [[File:Alligator gar fin maneuvers.webmhd.webm|thumb|180px|Alligator gar maneuvering with pectoral fins in large zoo aquarium|right]]
Alligator gar are the largest species in the gar family, and among the largest freshwater fishes found in North America. Mature alligator gar commonly measure {{Convert|6|ft|m|abbr=on}} in length, and weigh over 100 lb (45 kg). However, anecdotal reports suggest they can grow up to 10 ft (3 m) in length, and weigh as much as 350 lb (159 kg).<ref name=FLMNH>{{cite web|url=http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/natsci/ichthyology/gallery/Descript/AlligatorGar/AlligatorGar.html|publisher=FLMNH Ichthyology Department|title=Alligator Gar|author =Goddard, Nathaniel |accessdate=April 19, 2014}}</ref> The largest alligator gar officially recorded was inadvertently caught in the net of fisherman Kenny Williams of [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]], while he was fishing the [[oxbow lake]]s of the [[Mississippi River]] on February 14, 2011. Williams was pulling up his net on Lake Chotard expecting to find [[buffalo fish]], but instead discovered a large alligator gar tangled in his net. The gar was {{Convert|8|ft|5+1/4|in|abbr=on}} long, weighed {{Convert|327|lb|abbr=on}}, and its girth was {{Convert|47|in|cm|abbr=on}}. According to wildlife officials, the fish was estimated to be between 50 and 70 years old; one report estimated the gar's age to be at least 95.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tpwd.texas.gov/huntwild/wild/species/alg/ | title=Alligator Gar (Atractosteus spatula) | publisher=Texas Parks & Wildlife Department | accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref> Williams donated it to the [[Mississippi Museum of Natural Science]] in [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]], where it will remain on display.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wapt.com/Vicksburg-Man-Catches-327-Lb-Alligator-Gar/-/9157628/5991148/-/iqeqgv/-/index.html |title=Vicksburg Man Catches 327 Lb. Alligator Gar |publisher=WAPT News |date=February 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209014936/http://www.wapt.com/Vicksburg-Man-Catches-327-Lb-Alligator-Gar/-/9157628/5991148/-/iqeqgv/-/index.html |archivedate=February 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fieldandstream.com/photos/gallery/fishing/2011/02/world-record-gar-alligator-gar-monster-huge-mississippi|publisher=Field & Stream|title=World Record Alligator Gar Pulled From Mississippi Lake Tangled in Fisherman's Net|author =Love, Chad |date=February 23, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2014}}</ref> All gars have torpedo-shaped bodies, but some distinguishing characteristics of adult alligator gar include their large size; heavy bodies; broad heads; short, broad snouts; large, sharp teeth; and double row of teeth on their upper jaws. They are usually brown or olive fading to a lighter gray or yellow [[ventral]] surface. The [[Dorsal fin|dorsal]] and [[anal fin]]s are positioned toward the back of their bodies, and their [[caudal fin]]s are abbreviate-[[heterocercal]], or nonsymmetrical.<ref name=FLMNH/>
==Physiology== Alligator gar have [[gill]]s, but unlike other species of fish, with few exceptions, they also have a highly [[vascularized]] [[swim bladder]] lung that supplements gill respiration.<ref name=Tyus>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3B-PAfeyqbIC&pg=PA46| title=Ecology and Conservation of Fishes | publisher=CRC Press | author=Tyus, Harold M. | year=2011 | page=46 | isbn=9781439858547}}</ref> The bladder not only provides buoyancy, but also enables them to breathe in air, which is why they are able to inhabit bodies of water in which most other fishes would die of [[suffocation]]. The swim bladder is connected to their fore gut by a small [[pneumatic duct]] which allows them to breathe or gulp air when they break the surface,<ref name="WaEDU">{{cite web | url=http://courses.washington.edu/fish311/FISH%20311%20files/05-Swimbladder.pdf | title=Biology of Fishes-Fish/Biol 311 | publisher=University of Washington | work=Swimbladder | accessdate=August 2, 2014}}</ref> an action seen quite frequently on lakes in the [[Southern United States]] during the hot summer.
The scales of alligator gar are not like the scales of other fishes which have flexible [[elasmoid scale]]s; their bodies are protected by inflexible and articulated [[Ganoid scale|ganoid]] scales that are diamond-shaped, often with serrated edges, and composed of a tough inner layer of bone and hard outer layer of [[ganoin]] which is essentially homologous to tooth enamel, making them nearly impenetrable.<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2015/09/how-enamel-coats-your-teeth-evolved | title=How The Enamel That Coats Your Teeth Evolved | last=Perkins | first=Sid | publisher=AAAS | date=September 23, 2015 | accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name=abc>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-24/tooth-enamel-may-have-evolved-from-ancient-fish-scales/6801938 | title=Tooth Enamel May Have Evolved From Ancient Fish Scales | publisher=ABC Science | date=September 24, 2015 | accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name=JTRS>{{Cite journal|last=Sherman|first=Vincent R.|last2=Yaraghi|first2=Nicholas A.|last3=Kisailus|first3=David|last4=Meyers|first4=Marc A.|date=2016-12-01|title=Microstructural and geometric influences in the protective scales of Atractosteus spatula|url=http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/13/125/20160595|journal=Journal of The Royal Society Interface|language=en|volume=13|issue=125|pages=20160595|doi=10.1098/rsif.2016.0595|issn=1742-5689|pmid=27974575|pmc=5221522}}</ref>
==Taxonomy and evolution== [[Bernard Germain Étienne comte de La Ville-sur-Illon La Cépède|Lacépède]] first described the alligator gar in 1803. The original name was ''[[Lepisosteus spatula]]'', but was later changed by E.O. Wiley in 1976 to ''Atractosteus spatula'' to recognize two distinct [[extant taxon|taxa]] of gars. Synonyms of ''Atractosteus spatula'' include ''Lesisosteus'' [sic] ''ferox'' (Rafinesque 1820), and ''Lepisosteus spatula'' (Lacepede 1803). Fossils from the order [[Lepisosteiformes]] have been collected in [[Europe]] from the [[Cretaceous]] to [[Oligocene]] periods, in Africa and India from the Cretaceous, and in North America from the Cretaceous to recent times. The Lepisosteidae are the only extant family of gars which has seven species, all located in North and [[Central America]].<ref name=FLMNH/> The [[fossil record]] traces the existence of alligator gar back to the [[Early Cretaceous]] over a hundred million years ago.<ref name=ResearchGate>{{cite news|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259462324_Effects_of_salinity_on_growth_and_ion_regulation_of_juvenile_alligator_gar_Atractosteus_spatula|publisher=Mississippi State University Dept. of Wildlife, Fisheries and Aquaculture|title=Comparative biochemistry and physiology. Part A, Molecular and integrative physiology|author1=Schwartz, Daniel E. |author2=Allen, Peter J. |date=December 2013}}</ref><ref name=Naturalist>{{cite journal|title=The American Naturalist|volume=35|publisher=University of Chicago Press|jstor=2453768}}</ref> Despite being a highly evolved species, alligator gar are often referred to as "primitive fishes", or "living fossils"<ref name=Warren>{{cite book | isbn=1421412012| publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press | title=Freshwater Fishes of North America |author1=Warren, Melvin L. Jr. |author2=Burr, Brooks M. | page=250|volume= 1}}</ref><ref name="Fossils">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=CMsgQQkmFqQC&lpg=PA38&dq=alligator%20gars%20are%20living%20fossils&pg=PA38 | title=Fossil Legends of the First Americans | publisher=Princeton University Press | author=Mayor, Adrienne | year=2005 | page=38 | isbn=9781400849314}}</ref> because they have retained a few [[Morphological (biology)|morphological]] characteristics of their earliest ancestors with seemingly few to no apparent changes, such as a [[spiral valve]] intestine which is also common to the digestive system of sharks, an abbreviate-heterocercal tail, and a swim bladder lung for breathing in both air and water.<ref name=FLMNH/><ref name="Earthwave">{{cite web|url=http://www.earthwave.org/alligator_gar|title=Alligator Gar (Atractosteus spatula)|date=2011 |accessdate=January 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name="JBGraham">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=JQh3D3BFCZwC&pg=PP2 | title=Air-Breathing Fishes: Evolution, Diversity, and Adaptation | publisher=Academic Press | author=Graham, Jeffrey B. | year=1997 | pages=1–10 | isbn=0-12-294860-2}}</ref>
[[File:AlligatorGarHarvest.jpg|thumb|1995 [[Choke Canyon Reservoir]] controlled gar harvest]] [[File:Filleting an alligator gar.jpg|thumb|On site processing by commercial fishermen]] [[File:AlligatorGarPrice.jpg|thumb|Market display of gar fillets]] [[File:Alligator gar fillets on the grill.jpg|thumb|Gar fillets grilled and boiled]] [[File:Alligator gar ganoid scale jewelry.jpg|thumb|Ganoid scale jewelry]] [[File:Earrings from the ganoid scales of alligator gar.jpg|thumb|Ganoid scale earrings]]
==Feeding behavior== Alligator gar are relatively passive, seemingly sluggish solitary fish, but voracious [[ambush predator]]s. They are opportunistic night predators and are primarily [[piscivores]], but they also ambush and eat [[water fowl]] and small [[mammal]]s that may be floating on the surface. Their method of ambush is to float a few feet below the surface, and wait for unsuspecting [[prey]] to swim within reach. They lunge forward, and with a sweeping motion, grab their prey, impaling it on their double rows of sharp teeth.<ref name=Earthwave/>
Diet studies have shown alligator gar to be opportunistic piscivores, and even [[scavenger]]s depending on the availability of their preferred food source. They occasionally ingest sport fish, but the majority of stomach content studies suggest they feed predominately on [[forage fish]]es such as [[gizzard shad]] and [[invertebrate]]s and water fowl. Diet studies have also revealed fishing tackle and boat-engine parts in their stomachs.<ref name=MDC>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdafs.org/alligar/docs/Missouri%20Alligator%20Gar%20Management%20and%20Restoration%20Plan.pdf|title=Missouri Alligator Gar Management and Restoration Plan|publisher=Missouri Department of Conservation Fisheries Division|date=January 22, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506052518/http://sdafs.org/alligar/docs/Missouri%20Alligator%20Gar%20Management%20and%20Restoration%20Plan.pdf|archivedate=May 6, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="TPWDgar">{{cite web | url=http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/publications/nonpwdpubs/media/gar_status_073108.pdf | title=Life History and Status of Alligator Gar (Atractosteus spatula), with Recommendations for Management | publisher=Texas Parks and Wildlife Department | work=Heart of Hills Fisheries Science Center | date=July 31, 2008 | accessdate=July 7, 2014 | author=Buckmeier, David L. | page=5}}</ref>
==Spawning== As with most ancestral species, alligator gar are long-lived, and sexually late maturing. Most females do not reach sexual maturity until after their first decade of life, while males reach sexual maturity in half that time. The conditions must be precise for a successful spawning to occur. Preparation for spawning begins in the spring with the extended [[photoperiodism|photoperiod]] and rising water temperatures, but flooding is also necessary to trigger the event. When rivers rise and spread over the floodplain, they create [[oxbow lake]]s and [[Slough (hydrology)|sloughs]], and inundate terrestrial vegetation, which in turn provides protection and a nutrient-rich habitat for [[larval fish]] and [[Fish (fry)|fry]]. Once the water temperature has reached {{convert|68|to|82|F|C}}, and all the other criteria are met, gar move into the grassy, weed-laden shallows to spawn.<ref name="TCEQ">{{cite web | url=http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/assets/public/permitting/watersupply/water_rights/eflows/20091124snbbest_biologicoverlaydraft.pdf | title=BBest Recommendations Report | work=Sabine/Neches BBest Biological Overlay Approach | date=November 2, 2009 | accessdate=July 7, 2014 | publisher=Best Biological Subcommittee, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, U.S. | page=8 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924113434/http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/assets/public/permitting/watersupply/water_rights/eflows/20091124snbbest_biologicoverlaydraft.pdf | archive-date=September 24, 2015 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=Chron>{{cite web|publisher=Houston Chronicle|url=http://www.chron.com/sports/outdoors/article/Once-a-nuisance-alligator-gar-increasingly-5333046.php|title=Once a nuisance, alligator gar increasingly protected|author =Thompkins, Shannon |date=April 19, 2014}}</ref>
Actual spawning occurs when males gather around [[gravid]] females, and begin writhing, twisting, bumping into and slithering over the tops of females, an activity which triggers the release of eggs. Males release clouds of [[milt]] to fertilize the eggs as they are released into the water column.<ref name="TCEQ"/> The sticky eggs then attach to submerged vegetation, and development begins. Only a few days are needed for the eggs to hatch into larval fish, and another 10 days or so for the larval fish to detach from the vegetation and start moving about as young fry.<ref name=Chron/> Egg production is variable, and believed to be dependent on the size of the female. A common formula used for predicting the volume of eggs a female can produce is 4.1 eggs/gram of body weight, which gives an average of about 150,000 eggs per spawn. The eggs of alligator gar are bright red and poisonous to humans if ingested.<ref name=Earthwave/>
==Distribution== [[File:Alligator gar.jpg|thumb|250px|Alligator gar caught in Moon Lake, Mississippi, March 1910]]
===Natural range=== Alligator gar inhabit a wide variety of [[aquatic habitat]]s, but most are found in the Southern United States in reservoirs and lakes, in the backwaters of lowland rivers, and in the [[brackish water]]s of estuaries, bayous, and bays. They have occasionally been seen in the Gulf of Mexico.<ref name=Earthwave/> In Texas and Louisiana, large gars are commonly seen breaking the surface in reservoirs, bayous, and brackish marshes. They are found throughout the lower Mississippi River Valley and Gulf Coast states of the Southern United States and Mexico as far south as [[Veracruz]], encompassing these states: Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Kentucky, Mississippi, Alabama, Tennessee, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Florida, and Georgia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sdafs.org/alligar/index.html |title=Alligator Gar Technical Committee |publisher=Southern Division of the American Fisheries Society |accessdate=May 17, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104045227/http://www.sdafs.org/alligar/index.html |archivedate=November 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Reports suggest alligator gar were once numerous throughout much of their northern range, but valid sightings today are rare, and may occur once every few years.<ref name=FLMNH/> Records of historical distribution indicate alligator gar once inhabited regions as far north as central Kansas, Nebraska, Ohio, Iowa, and west-central Illinois, where they are now listed as [[Local extinction|extirpated]]. The most northerly verified catch was in [[Meredosia, Illinois]], in 1922.<ref name="il-acad-sci.org">{{cite journal |last=Poly |first=William J. |year=2001 |url=http://www.calacademy.org:8080/sites/default/files/assets/ibss/departments/ichthyology/poly_2001_tisas.pdf |title=Distribution of the Alligator Gar, Atractosteus spatula (Lacépède, 1803), in Illinois |journal=Transactions of the Illinois State Academy of Science |volume=94 |issue=3 |pages=185–190 |access-date=July 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809122049/http://www.calacademy.org:8080/sites/default/files/assets/ibss/departments/ichthyology/poly_2001_tisas.pdf |archive-date=August 9, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Now, efforts to reintroduce alligator gar between Tennessee and Illinois are being made as part of an effort to control invasive [[Asian carp]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Webber|first1=Tammy|title=Huge, once-hated fish now seen as weapon against Asian carp|url=http://www.pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/huge-once-hated-fish-now-seen-as-weapon-against-asian/article_471ed568-2b6f-583d-b5c9-0b490a9d48e5.html|accessdate=July 31, 2016|work=Pantagraph|agency=Associated Press|date=July 29, 2016}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Outside natural range=== A few notable sightings of alligator gar have been reported outside North America. In November 2008, a broadhead gar, genus ''Atractosteus'', measuring {{convert|5.2|to|6.4|ft|abbr=on}} was caught in the [[Caspian Sea]] north of [[Esenguly]], [[Turkmenistan]], by two officials of Turkmenistan Fishery Protection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cawater-info.net/ca/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=495:hazar-dezini-tuerkmen-kenarynda-amerikan-sowutly-cortany-tutulmagyny-ilkinji-wakasy&catid=43:news-turkmen&Itemid=37 |title=Hazar deňziniň türkmen kenarynda amerikan sowutly çortanyň tutulmagynyň ilkinji wakasy |publisher=Türkmenistanyň Tebigaty goramak ministrligi |language=Turkmen |accessdate=May 18, 2015}}</ref> Its species is unconfirmed, but is believed to be an alligator gar.<ref name=ERJ>{{cite journal|doi=10.1134/S2075111711030118|publisher=Springer|work=Erratum to: "First Finding of Gar ''Atractosteus'' sp. (Actinopterygii, Lepisosteiformes, Lepisosteidae) in the Caspian Sea near the Coast of Turkmenistan" | title=''Russian Journal of Biological Invasions'' |author =Salnikov, V. B. |volume=2|issue=2-3|page=240|date=April 2011}}</ref>
On September 4, 2009, a {{convert|3|ft|3|in|adj=on|abbr=on}} alligator gar was found in Tak Wah Park in [[Tsuen Wan]], [[Hong Kong]]. Over the next two days, at least 16 other alligator gar, the largest measuring {{Convert|4.9|ft|abbr=on}}, were found in ponds in public parks in Hong Kong.<ref name=ABS>{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/classified-odd/09/07/09/monster-exotic-fish-found-hong-kong-ponds|title=Monster Exotic Fish Found In Hong Kong Ponds|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=September 5, 2009|accessdate=July 4, 2016}}</ref> Nearby residents reported the alligator gar had been released into the ponds by [[aquarium]] hobbyists, and had lived there for several years. However, after a complaint made by a citizen who falsely identified alligator gar as [[crocodile]]s, the use of terms like "horrible man-eating fish" had begun appearing in the headlines of some major local newspapers. Officials with Leisure and Cultural Services in Tak Wah Park removed all the alligator gar from the ponds because they were concerned the large, carnivorous fish might harm children.<ref name=SCMP>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/703297/feared-public-ponds-admired-behind-glass|publisher=South China Morning Post|title=Feared in public ponds, admired behind glass|author =Nip, Amy |date=January 10, 2010}}</ref> Not unusually, the large, sharp teeth and outward appearance of alligator gar can precipitate unreasonable fear in those unfamiliar with the species. Sensationalized reports have contributed to the misconception of predatory attacks by alligator gar on humans, though none of the reports has been confirmed.<ref name=SMSUP>{{cite web|url=http://www.semopress.com/when-gars-attack/|publisher=Southeast Missouri State University|title=When Gars Attack|author =Spitzer, Mark|accessdate=July 4, 2016}}</ref>
On January 21, 2011, an alligator gar measuring {{convert|4|ft|11|in|abbr=on}} was caught in a canal in [[Pasir Ris]], [[Singapore]], by two recreational fishermen. The fish was taken to a nearby pond, where the owner confirmed it was an alligator gar rather than an [[arapaima]] as the men had initially thought.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://singaporeseen.stomp.com.sg/this-urban-jungle/friends-catch-15m-monster-fish-from-pasir-ris-canal-after-long-struggle |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220120342/http://singaporeseen.stomp.com.sg/this-urban-jungle/friends-catch-15m-monster-fish-from-pasir-ris-canal-after-long-struggle |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 20, 2016 |title=Friends Catch 1.5m 'Monster' Fish From Pasir Ris Canal After Long Struggle |work=The Straits Times |date=January 21, 2011 }}</ref>
Anecdotal reports have been made of alligator gar captured in various parts of India, but are believed to be the result of incidental releases by aquarium hobbyists and the like. In August 2015, an alligator gar was found entangled in cloth inside a well in [[Dadar]], where it had been living for quite some time. It was rescued by animal activists and returned to the well unharmed.<ref name=Singh>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Exotic-Alligator-Gar-fish-rescued-in-Dadar/articleshow/48379367.cms | title=Exotic Alligator Gar fish rescued in Dadar | publisher = Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd | work = The Times of India | author = Singh, Vijay | date = August 6, 2015 | accessdate = December 6, 2015}}</ref> In June 2016, a 3.5 ft Alligator Gar was caught from Subhash Sarovar Lake in Kolkata.<ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/kolkata/kolkata-discovery-of-predator-fish-that-resembles-an-alligator-concerns-experts/story-0fkEMG3VAcgCouDRFGQgEM.html Kolkata: Discovery of predator fish that resembles an alligator concerns experts]. Hindustan Times (June 22, 2016). Retrieved on 2016-11-10.</ref> Other incidents over the years have been random, ranging from captures in coastal waters during environmental assessments<ref name = NIC>{{cite web | url=http://planningcommission.nic.in/reports/sereport/ser/stdy_coral.pdf | title = Studies on Socioeconomics of Coral Reef Resource Users in the Gulf of Mannar Coast, South India | work = Planning Commission Project | publisher = Centre for Marine and Coastal Studies | authors = Kumaraguru, A.K.; Kannan, R. and Sundaramahalingam, A. | date = March 2000 | accessdate = December 6, 2015}}</ref> to captures in private ponds.
==Human uses==
===Early history=== [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in the south, and [[Caribbean people]]s used the alligator gar's [[Ganoid|ganoid scales]] for arrow heads, breastplates, and as shielding to cover plows. [[European colonization of the Americas|Early settlers]] [[Tanning (leather)|tanned]] the skins to make a strong, durable leather to cover their wooden plows, and make purses and various other items. Gar oil was also used by the people of Arkansas as a repellent for buffalo gnats.<ref name=MDC/>
For nearly half a century, alligator gar were considered "trash fish",<ref name=FWS/> or "nuisance species" by state and federal authorities who targeted them for elimination to protect gamefish populations,<ref name="WarmSpringsNFH"/> and to prevent alleged attacks on humans, a claim that remains unsubstantiated with the exception of occasional injuries sustained from captured alligator gar thrashing around on the decks of boats.<ref name="Earthwave" /> Fishermen participated in the slaughter of thousands of alligator gar believing they were providing a great service. In 1992, PBS affiliate [[KUHT]] channel 8, became the presenting station for a public outreach program that documented the life history cycle of alligator gar titled ''The Alligator Gar: Predator or Prey?''. It was the first documentary ever produced and televised nationally about alligator gar at a time when it was still being referred to as a trash fish. The half-hour program ran for 3 years as part of an educational series titled, "Exotic and Unusual Fishes", produced by Earthwave Society. It first aired in primetime during the 1992 July [[Nielsen ratings#Sweeps|sweeps]], and drew a 2.8 rating/4 share, making it the number-one rated program of the evening for PBS.<ref name="Earthwave" /> A decade passed before any significant action was taken to protect and preserve the remaining populations of alligator gar in the United States. Among the first to enact restoration and management practices was the [[Missouri Department of Conservation]] in partnership with Tennessee, Arkansas, Kentucky, Illinois, Alabama, Mississippi, Texas, Oklahoma, and Louisiana.<ref name=MDC/>
===Sport fish=== [[File:Alligator Gar 6 Feet 129 lbs Brazos River 8 Nov 04a.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A {{convert|6|ft|m|adj=on|abbr=on}} {{convert|129|lb|kg|adj=on|abbr=on}} alligator gar caught in Texas, 2004]]
The long-time public perception of alligator gar as trash fish or a nuisance species has changed, with increasing national and international attention on the species as a sport fish, which some have attributed to features on popular television shows. Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas, Mississippi, and Louisiana allow regulated [[sport fishing]] of alligator gar. Texas has one of the best remaining fisheries for alligator gar, and in concert with its efforts to maintain a viable fishery, imposed a one-per-day bag limit on them in 2009.<ref name="TPWD">{{cite web | url=http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/huntwild/wild/species/alg/ | title=Alligator Gar | publisher=Texas Parks and Wildlife Department | accessdate=April 21, 2014}}</ref> The Texas state record, and world record for the largest alligator gar caught on rod and reel, is {{Convert|279|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, taken by Bill Valverde on January 1, 1951, on the Rio Grande in Texas.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/fishboat/fish/action/staterecords.php?env=FW&age_group=all&list=0&browse=Submit |title=State Freshwater Records: Rod and Reel |publisher=Texas Parks & Wildlife |accessdate=May 17, 2013}}</ref> Alligator gar are also quite popular among [[bowfishing|bowfishers]] because of their large size, trophy potential, and fighting ability. The Texas state bowfishing record was set in 2001 by Marty McClellan with a {{convert|290|lb|adj=on|abbr=on}} alligator gar from the Trinity River. The all-tackle record was a {{convert|302|lb|adj=on|abbr=on}} alligator gar caught on a trotline in 1953 by T.C. Pierce, Jr. In 1991, fishing guide Kirk Kirkland anecdotally reported catching an alligator gar measuring {{convert|9|ft|6|in|abbr=on}} on rod and line from the Trinity River.<ref name="TPWDpress">{{cite web|url=http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/newsmedia/releases/print.phtml?req=20110516c|publisher=Texas Parks & Wildlife|title=Big Fish Stories Can Have Happier Endings|date=May 16, 2011}}</ref>
===Commercialization and aquaculture=== Declining populations of alligator gar throughout their historic range has resulted in the need to monitor wild populations and regulate commercial harvests. Alligator gar have a high yield of white meat filets and a small percentage of waste relative to body weight. The meat is sold to wholesale distributors, and also sold retail by a few supermarkets with prices starting at around $3.00/lb. Fried gar balls, grilled fillets, and filets boiled in water with [[crab boil]] seasoning are popular dishes in the south. Also, a small [[cottage industry]] makes jewelry out of ganoid scales, and tans gar hides to produce leather for making lamp shades, purses, and a host of novelty items.<ref name=Earthwave/><ref name=MDC/>
''Atractosteus'' gars, including alligator gar, [[tropical gar]]s, and [[Cuban gar]]s are considered good candidates for [[aquaculture]], particularly in developing regions, where their rapid growth, disease resistance, easy adaptation to artificial feeds as juveniles, and ability to tolerate low water quality are essential. Their ability to breathe in both air and water eliminates the need for costly aeration systems and other technology commonly used in aquaculture. In the Southern United States, as well as in parts of Mexico and Cuba, [[broodstock]]s have already been established, and are being maintained in their respective regions where they already are a popular food fish.<ref name="Ecofisiologia">{{cite web | url=http://www.ecofisiologia.com.mx/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/2008-Gar-biology-and-culture.pdf | title=Gar biology and culture: status and prospects | publisher=Aquaculture Research | work=Chapter 39 | date=2008 | accessdate=July 7, 2014 | author=Alfaro, Roberto M. |author2=Gonzales, Carlos A. |author3=Ferrara, Allyse | pages=748–763}}</ref>
===Aquaria=== Despite the large size alligator gar can attain, they are kept as aquarium fish, though many fish labeled as "alligator gar" in the aquarium trade are actually smaller species. Alligator gar require a very large aquarium or pond, and ample resources for them to thrive in captivity. They are also a popular fish for public aquaria, and zoos. In many areas, keeping alligator gar as pets is illegal, but they occasionally show up in fish stores. Alligator gar are highly prized and sought after for private aquaria, particularly in Japan. According to some reports, large alligator gar could fetch as much as US$40,000 in what some consider the "Japanese black market".<ref>{{cite news |last=Horswell |first=Cindy |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/7614483.html |title=Indictments accuse 3 of taking alligator gar fish out of Trinity |work=Houston Chronicle |date=June 17, 2011}}</ref> In June 2011, three men from Florida and Louisiana were indicted on charges of illegally removing wild alligator gar from the [[Trinity River (Texas)|Trinity River]] in Texas, and attempting to ship them to Japan for private collectors. The [[indictment]]s resulted from an undercover sting operation by [[special agent]]s with the [[U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service]], the [[Texas Parks and Wildlife Department]], and the [[Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2011-10-15/news/fl-alligator-gar-arrests-20111015_1_alligator-gar-fish-tales-trash-fish|work=SunSentinel | title=Monster fish tale: Alligator gar sting ends in conviction | author=Berstein, Jon |date= October 15, 2011}}</ref> The charges included violations of three separate provisions of the Lacey Act, specifically conspiracy to submit a false label for fish transported in interstate commerce; conspiracy to transport fish in interstate commerce in violation of state law or regulation; and conspiracy to transport and sell fish in interstate commerce in violation of state law or regulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktre.com/story/14917145/accused-alligator-gar-smugglers-busted-in-trinity-river-operation|title=Accused alligator gar smugglers busted in trinity river operation|publisher=ABC 9 KTRE|year=2011}}</ref> Two of the conspirators entered guilty pleas to one count, and the government dropped the other two charges against them. A third conspirator went to trial on all three counts, was acquitted on one count, and found guilty on two. The [[United States district court|district court]] sentenced him to serve nine months in prison followed by one year of [[Parole|supervised release]].<ref name=Justice>{{cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/enrd/legacy/2015/04/13/nov_2012_508.pdf|title=United States v. Loren Willis et al., Nos. 9:11-CR-00028, 1:11-CR-20676 (E.D. Tex., S.D. Fla.), AUSAs Reynaldo Morin and Jaime Raiche|publisher=Regional EnvironmentalEnforcement Association|work=Monthly Bulletin|date=October 2012|accessdate=July 4, 2016}}</ref> The case was appealed, and on April 15, 2014, the appellate court affirmed the judgment of the district court.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions%5Cunpub%5C12/12-41113.0.pdf |publisher=U.S. Court of Appeals |title=Opinions |date=April 15, 2014}}</ref>

{{Italic title}} [[File:Ars.moriendi.pride.a.jpg|thumb|[[Pride]] of the spirit is one of the five temptations of the dying man, according to '''''Ars moriendi'''''. Here, [[Demons#In Christian myth and legend|demons]] tempt the dying man with crowns (a [[medieval allegory]] to earthly pride) under the disapproving gaze of [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]], [[Christ]] and God. Woodblock seven (4a) of eleven, [[Netherlands]], circa 1460.]]
The '''''Ars moriendi''''' ("The Art of Dying") are two related [[Latin]] texts dating from about 1415 and 1450 which offer advice on the protocols and procedures of a good [[death]], explaining how to "die well" according to [[Christianity|Christian]] precepts of the [[late Middle Ages]]. It was written within the historical context of the effects of the macabre horrors of the [[Black Death]] 60 years earlier and consequent [[Crisis of the Late Middle Ages|social upheavals of the 15th century]]. It was very popular, translated into most West European languages, and was the first in a western literary tradition of guides to death and dying. About 50,000 copies were printed in the ''incunabula'' period before 1501.<ref name=":0" />
There was originally a "long version" and a later "short version" containing eleven [[woodcut]] pictures as instructive images which could be easily explained and memorized.
The authors of the two texts are unknown, but assumed to be Dominican churchmen, as they echo Jean de Gerson's publication, the ''Opusculum Tripartitu'', containing a section named ''De arte Moriendi''. Gerson may have been influenced by earlier references in 'compendia of faith' dating back to the thirteenth century, but the content was uniquely his own.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Paul|first1=Kathryn|title=The Ars Moriendi: A Practical Approach To Dying Well|journal=Modern Believing|date=2015|volume=56|issue=2|page=213|doi=10.3828/mb.2015.19|publisher=ATLASerials|language=English|issn=1353-1425}}</ref>
== Long version == The original "long version", called ''Tractatus'' (or ''[[Speculum literature|Speculum]]'') ''artis bene moriendi'', was composed in 1415 by an anonymous [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] friar, probably at the request of the [[Council of Constance]] (1414–1418, Germany).<ref name=blake>N.F. Blake (1982). "Ars Moriendi". ''Dictionary of the Middle Ages''. v.1, pp547-8. {{ISBN|0-684-16760-3}}</ref> This was widely read and translated into most West European languages, and was very popular in England, where a tradition of consolatory death literature survived until the 17th century. Works in the English tradition include ''[[The Way of Dying Well]]'' and ''[[The Sick Mannes Salve]]''. In 1650, ''[[Holy Living and Holy Dying]]'' became the "artistic climax" of the tradition that had begun with ''Ars moriendi''.<ref>Nancy Beaty (1970). ''The Craft of Dying: A Study of the Literary Traditions of the Ars Moriendi in England''. {{ISBN|0-300-01336-1}}</ref>
''Ars Moriendi'' was also among the first books printed with movable type and was widely circulated in nearly 100 editions before 1500, in particular in Germany. The long version survives in about 300 manuscript versions, only one illustrated.
''Ars moriendi'' consists of six chapters:<ref name=blake />
# The first chapter explains that dying has a good side, and serves to console the dying man that death is not something to be afraid of. # The second chapter outlines the five temptations that beset a dying man, and how to avoid them. These are [[faith|lack of faith]], [[wikt:despair|despair]], [[patience|impatience]], [[pride|spiritual pride]] and [[avarice]]. # The third chapter lists the seven questions to ask a dying man, along with consolation available to him through the redemptive powers of [[Christ]]'s love. # The fourth chapter expresses the need to imitate Christ's life. # The fifth chapter addresses the friends and family, outlining the general rules of behavior at the deathbed. # The sixth chapter includes appropriate [[prayer]]s to be said for a dying man.
== Short version == The "short version", whose appearance shortly precedes the introduction in the 1460s of [[Woodblock printing|block books]] (books printed from carved blocks of wood, both text and images on the same block), first dates to around 1450, from the [[Netherlands]].<ref name=blake /> It is mostly an adaptation of the second chapter of the "long version", and contains eleven woodcut pictures. The first ten woodcuts are divided into 5 pairs, with each set showing a picture of [[Christian teaching about the Devil|the devil]] presenting one of the 5 temptations, and the second picture showing the proper remedy for that temptation. The last woodcut shows the dying man, presumably having successfully navigated the maze of temptations, being accepted into [[heaven]], and the devils going back to [[Hell in Christian beliefs|hell]] in confusion.
The "short version" was as popular as the "long version", but there was no English translation, perhaps because educated English people at the time were expected to understand several European languages. There are six extant manuscripts of the short version, most not illustrated, and over twenty extant blockbook illustrated editions, using 13 different sets of blocks.<ref>A Hyatt Mayor (1971), ''Prints and People'', Metropolitan Museum of Art/Princeton, numbers 23-25.{{ISBN|0-691-00326-2}}</ref>
[[File:Ars moriendi (Meister E.S.), L.175.png|thumb|''Temptation of lack of Faith''; engraving by [[Master E. S.]], circa 1450]]
== The images == As well as the eleven different sets of [[blockbook]] [[woodcut]]s, there is a set by [[Master E. S.]] in [[engraving]]. The lengthy controversy over their respective dating and priority is now resolved by the discovery by [[Fritz Saxl]] of an earlier illuminated manuscript, of well before 1450, from whose tradition all the images in the printed versions clearly derive. Studies of the [[watermark]]s of the blockbooks by Allen Stevenson at the [[British Museum]] in the 1960s confirmed that none of them predated the 1460s, so Master E. S.' engravings are the earliest printed versions, dating from around 1450. The images remain largely the same in all media for the rest of the century.<ref>Alan Shestack (1967). ''Master E. S.'', exhibition catalogue, Philadelphia Museum of Art, exhibit numbers 4-15</ref>
There is the exceptional number of about seventy [[incunabulum]] editions, in a variety of languages, from Catalan to Dutch, the earliest from about 1474 from [[Cologne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://138.253.81.72/~cheshire/cgi-bin/istc/istcsearch.cgi?squery=search++(topicWord+%5C%5B5%3D100%5C%5D+%7B+ars+moriendi+%7D+)+resultsetid+SearchResults&recno=1&sorttype1=attr&sortfield1=istcnum |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006210256/http://138.253.81.72/~cheshire/cgi-bin/istc/istcsearch.cgi?squery=search++%28topicWord+%5C%5B5%3D100%5C%5D+%7B+ars+moriendi+%7D+%29+resultsetid+SearchResults&recno=1&sorttype1=attr&sortfield1=istcnum |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-06 |title=ISTC, British Library |publisher=138.253.81.72 |date=2005-10-27 |accessdate=2013-01-14 }}</ref>
Allegorically the images depicted the contest between angels and demons over the fate of the dying man. In his dying agony his soul emerges from his mouth to be received by one of a band of angels. Common themes portrayed by illustrators include skeletons, the Last Judgement, corpses, and the forces of good and evil battling over souls.<ref name=":0">Martyn Lyons (2011). ''Books: A Living History''. {{ISBN|978-1-60606-083-4}}</ref>
== Extended tradition == The popularity of the ''Ars moriendi'' texts developed into a broader tradition of writing on the good death. Jeremy Taylor's books ''[[Holy Living and Holy Dying]]'', published in 1650 and 1651, exemplify that tradition. It developed in both Protestant and Catholic veins and continued in various forms through the nineteenth century.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:George Cross.jpg|thumb|right|120px|[[George Cross]] and its [[ribbon bar]]]] '''Brian Spillett''' [[George Cross|GC]] (July 21st 1937 – 16 January 1965) he was the only son of Ernest and Mary Spillett (nee Madison) and brother to Christine, Rosemary, and Irene Spillett, he was [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] awarded the [[George Cross]], the highest [[United Kingdom|British]] (and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]]) award for bravery out of combat.<ref name=GCDB>{{cite web |url=http://www.gc-database.co.uk/recipients/SpillettB.htm |title=Brian Spillett, GC |publisher=George Cross database |accessdate=22 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116142013/http://www.gc-database.co.uk/recipients/SpillettB.htm |archivedate=16 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Mr Spillett died of burns he received while trying to save a neighbour in Lodge Crescent, Waltham Cross, [[Hertfordshire]] in Chase Farm Hospital in Enfield. He was a [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] [[Lance-Bombardier]] in P Battery, 289 Parachute Light Regiment, [[Royal Horse Artillery]] and in civilian life worked as a fitter. His George Cross was announced in a supplement to the [[London Gazette]] of 25 June 1965, and dated 29 June 1965. <ref name=LG1>{{London Gazette |issue=43698 |date=25 June 1965 |pages=6203–6204
|supp=y }}</ref>
The London Gazette citation describes how Spillett became aware that there was a fire at a neighbouring house where three generations of a family lived. Spillett arrived, still only partly dressed, to learn that the father Mr Palmer of the family was still in the house. The whole house was already well alight, but he went in despite being held back by other neighbours. He managed to fight his way upstairs but was unable to get through to the trapped man. He himself became trapped and had to escape the flames by jumping from a first floor window. Once the fire was over, he was found in the garden of a neighbour after crawling down the garden, through the alley and thinking he was crawling to his own back door to his wife , ended up at the back door of a neighbour, badly burned and with other serious injuries, from jumping and falling through the leanto. He was taken to hospital but died a week later. He leaves behind a young wife Jean and four month old daughter Jacqueline Spillett.

[[File:Location Cambodia ASEAN.svg|thumb|150 px|Location of Cambodia on the map]] '''Capital punishment in Cambodia''' has been abolished.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/death-penalty/abolitionist-and-retentionist-countries|title=Death Penalty|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Cambodia]] abolished the [[death penalty]] in 1989.<ref name="handsoffcain.info">{{cite web|url=http://www.handsoffcain.info/bancadati/schedastato.php?idstato=17000221|title=HANDS OFF CAIN against death penalty in the world|publisher=}}</ref>
The [[Constitution of Cambodia|Constitution of the Kingdom of Cambodia]] (1993) at Art. 32 states:<ref name="handsoffcain.info"/> :"All people have the [[right to life]], freedom and personal security. There shall be no capital punishment."
In 1995, First Prime Minister Prince [[Norodom Ranariddh]] made calls for [[Capital punishment]] by calling for murderers and drug traffickers to be killed by the State.<ref>https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/why-capital-punishment-bad-idea-cambodia</ref>

{{About|different cell types within a species|coverage regarding [[eukaryote]]s and [[prokaryote]]s|Cell (biology)}}
A '''cell type''' is a classification used to distinguish between [[Morphology (biology)|morphologically]] or [[Phenotype|phenotypically]] distinct [[cell (biology)|cell]] forms within a [[species]]. A [[multicellular organism]] may contain a number of widely differing and specialized cell types, such as [[muscle cell]]s and [[skin cell]]s in humans, that differ both in appearance and function yet are [[Genetics|genetically]] identical. Cells are able to be of the same [[genotype]], but different cell type due to the differential [[Regulation of gene expression|regulation]] of the [[gene]]s they contain. [[Cell fate determination#Cell fate|Classification]] of a specific cell type is often done through the use of [[microscopy]] (such as those from the [[cluster of differentiation]] family that are commonly used for this purpose in [[immunology]]). Recent developments in [[Single cell sequencing|single cell RNA sequencing]] facilitated classification of cell types based on shared gene expression patterns. This has led to the discovery of many new cell types in e.g. mouse [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]], [[hippocampus]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zeisel|first=Amit|last2=Muñoz-Manchado|first2=Ana B.|last3=Codeluppi|first3=Simone|last4=Lönnerberg|first4=Peter|last5=Manno|first5=Gioele La|last6=Juréus|first6=Anna|last7=Marques|first7=Sueli|last8=Munguba|first8=Hermany|last9=He|first9=Liqun|date=2015-03-06|title=Cell types in the mouse cortex and hippocampus revealed by single-cell RNA-seq|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/347/6226/1138|journal=Science|language=en|volume=347|issue=6226|pages=1138–1142|doi=10.1126/science.aaa1934|issn=0036-8075|pmid=25700174}}</ref> [[dorsal root ganglion]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Usoskin|first=Dmitry|last2=Furlan|first2=Alessandro|last3=Islam|first3=Saiful|last4=Abdo|first4=Hind|last5=Lönnerberg|first5=Peter|last6=Lou|first6=Daohua|last7=Hjerling-Leffler|first7=Jens|last8=Haeggström|first8=Jesper|last9=Kharchenko|first9=Olga|date=2014-11-24|title=Unbiased classification of sensory neuron types by large-scale single-cell RNA sequencing|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nn.3881|journal=Nature Neuroscience|language=En|volume=18|issue=1|pages=145–153|doi=10.1038/nn.3881|issn=1097-6256}}</ref> and [[spinal cord]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Häring|first=Martin|last2=Zeisel|first2=Amit|last3=Hochgerner|first3=Hannah|last4=Rinwa|first4=Puneet|last5=Jakobsson|first5=Jon E. T.|last6=Lönnerberg|first6=Peter|last7=La Manno|first7=Gioele|last8=Sharma|first8=Nilesh|last9=Borgius|first9=Lotta|date=2018-04-23|title=Neuronal atlas of the dorsal horn defines its architecture and links sensory input to transcriptional cell types|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-018-0141-1|journal=Nature Neuroscience|language=En|volume=21|issue=6|pages=869–880|doi=10.1038/s41593-018-0141-1|issn=1097-6256}}</ref>
Animals have evolved a greater diversity of cell types in a [[multicellular]] body (100–150 different cell types), compared with 10–20 in plants, fungi, and protoctists.<ref>Margulis, L. & Chapman, M.J. (2009). Kingdoms and Domains: An Illustrated Guide to the Phyla of Life on Earth ([4th ed.]. ed.). Amsterdam: Academic Press/Elsevier. p. 116.</ref>
==Multicellular organisms== All higher [[multicellular organism|multicellular]] [[organism]]s contain cells specialised for different functions. Most distinct cell types arise from a single [[totipotent]] cell that [[Cellular differentiation|differentiates]] into hundreds of different cell types during the course of [[Development (biology)|development]]. Differentiation of cells is driven by different environmental cues (such as cell–cell interaction) and intrinsic differences (such as those caused by the uneven distribution of [[molecule]]s during [[cell division|division]]). [[multicellular organisms|Multicellular]] organisms are composed of cells that fall into two fundamental types: [[germ cell]]s and [[somatic cell]]s. During development, somatic cells will become more specialized and form the three primary [[germ layer]]s: [[ectoderm]], [[mesoderm]], and [[endoderm]]. After formation of the three [[germ layer]]s, cells will continue to specialize until they reach a terminally differentiated state that is much more resistant to changes in cell type than its [[Progenitor cell|progenitors]].
==Humans== A [[list of distinct cell types in the adult human body|list of cell types in the human body]] may include several hundred distinct types depending on the source.<ref>''Molecular Biology of the Cell'', Fourth Edition, Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, Peter Walter</ref><ref>[http://www.copewithcytokines.de/cope.cgi?key=cell%20types ines.de/cope.cgi COPE database]</ref>

[[Image:Chimpanzee congo painting.jpg|thumb|A painting by Congo]] '''Congo''' (1954–1964) was a [[chimpanzee]] who learned how to draw and paint. Zoologist, author and [[surrealist]] painter, [[Desmond Morris]], first observed his abilities when the chimp was offered a pencil and paper at two years of age. By the age of four, Congo had made 400 drawings and paintings. His style has been described as "lyrical [[abstract impressionism]]".<ref name="timesonline">{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article569970.ece |title=Congo the chimpanzee |accessdate=2008-12-12 |author=Waldemar Januszczak |work=[[TimesOnline]] |date=2005-09-25 | location=London}}</ref>
==Biography and works== Congo was born in 1954.<!--where?--> He learned to draw near the age of two, beginning when zoologist [[Desmond Morris]] offered Congo a pencil.<ref name="telegraph" /> Morris said, "He took a [[pencil]] and I placed a piece of card in front of him. This is how I recorded it at the time, 'Something strange was coming out of the end of the pencil. It was Congo's first line. It wandered a short way and then stopped. Would it happen again? Yes, it did, and again and again'."<ref name="telegraph" /> Morris soon observed that the chimp would draw [[circle]]s, and had a basic sense of composition in his drawings.<ref name="telegraph" /> He also showed the ability of symmetrical consistency between two sides of a sketch; when Morris drew a shape at one side of a piece of paper, Congo would balance the structure by making marks on the other half of the paper.<ref name="telegraph" /> Similarly, if a color on one side contained blue for example, he would add blue to the other side as well to keep balance.<ref name="timesonline" />
He soon began painting; the patterns he made were never distinguished, pictorial images, but usually of a vague "radiating fan pattern" in the [[abstract impressionism]] style.<ref name="telegraph" /> Between the ages of two and four, he produced about 400 drawings and paintings.<ref name="cbs">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/06/20/entertainment/main703057.shtml|title=Dead Chimp's Art Sells Big|accessdate=2008-06-01|date=2005-06-20|publisher=CBS News}}</ref>
Through that time, Congo developed a familiarity with his routine painting sessions with Morris. When a picture was taken away that he didn't consider complete, Congo would reportedly begin to scream and "throw fits".<ref name="timesonline" /> Also, if the ape considered one of his drawings to be finished, he would refuse to continue painting even if someone tried to persuade him to do so.<ref name="timesonline" />
In the late 1950s, he made appearances on the British television show Zootime, which was presented live from the [[London Zoo]] by Desmond Morris.<ref name="timesonline" /> He died at ten years of age in 1964 of [[tuberculosis]].<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1492463/Art-world-goes-wild-for-chimpanzees-paintings-as-Warhol-work-flops.html |title=Art world goes wild for chimpanzee's paintings as Warhol work flops |work=[[Telegraph.co.uk]] |date=2008-06-21 |accessdate=2008-12-10 | location=London | first=Nigel | last=Reynolds}}</ref>
==Reception== Media reaction to Congo's painting abilities were mixed, although relatively positive and accepted with interest. Spanish painter [[Pablo Picasso]] was reportedly a "fan" of his paintings, and hung one of the ape's pictures on his studio wall after receiving it as a gift.<ref name="timesonline" /><ref name="cbs" />
On June 20, 2005, Congo's paintings were included in an auction at [[Bonhams]] alongside works by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]] and [[Warhol]]—they sold for more than expected, while Renoir's and Warhol's did not sell. American collector Howard Hong purchased three of Congo's works for over US$25,000.<ref name="cbs" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4712948|title=No Chump Change for Chimp Art|accessdate=2008-06-01| date = 2005-06-21|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtop.com/?nid=502&sid=605428|title=Paintings by Chimpanzee Outsell Warhol, Renoir at Auction|accessdate=2008-06-01|date=2005-11-29|publisher=Wtopnews.com}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Animal-made art]] *[[Pierre Brassau]] *[[Pockets Warhol (capuchin monkey)]] *[[Tillamook Cheddar (dog)]]

[[File:Princess Victoria and Dash by George Hayter.jpg|thumb|right|Dash with Princess Victoria, by Sir [[George Hayter]], 1833]] '''Dash''' (1830–1840) was a [[King Charles Spaniel]] owned by [[Queen Victoria]]. Victoria's biographer [[Elizabeth Pakenham, Countess of Longford|Elizabeth Longford]], called him "the Queen's closest childhood companion",Longford, p. 155 and in the words of the ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', he "was the first in a long line of beloved little dogs".Matthew and Reynolds He was given to Victoria's mother, the [[Princess Victoria of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld|Duchess of Kent]], on 14 January 1833 by Sir [[John Conroy]], the [[Comptroller]] of the Duchess's household.Longford, p. 46 By the end of April 1833, he had become Victoria's companion, and by Christmas that year she was doting on him, giving him a set of rubber balls and two pieces of gingerbread as presents. In return, the dog was loyal to Victoria; on one occasion she went sailing on a yacht, and Dash leapt from the coastline into the sea and swam after her. Victoria, who was 13 when given Dash, had few if any childhood friends as she was raised largely isolated from other children under the so-called "[[Kensington System]]", an elaborate set of rules and protocols devised by the Duchess and Conroy.Longford, pp. 35–38, 118–119; Woodham-Smith, pp. 70–72 The only girl of a similar age with whom she had regular contact was Conroy's youngest daughter, [[Victoire Conroy|Victoire]], but they seemed to have had only a formal acquaintanceship.See, for example, Woodham-Smith, p. 111 In her diary, Victoria refers to Victoire as "Miss Conroy" but the dog is showered with endearments: "dear sweet little Dash" and "dear Dashy".Woodham-Smith, p. 91 In November 1834, Victoria and her mother took a holiday at [[St Leonards-on-Sea]]. They, with Dash, [[Lady Flora Hastings]] and [[Baroness Louise Lehzen]], were driving in a [[Landau (carriage)|landau]] drawn by two horses when the horses got caught in the traces and fell. With the horses struggling on the ground, there was a danger the carriage would overturn, injuring the women. Victoria scrambled out with Dash in her arms, and, as she recalled, "ran on with him in my arms calling Mama to follow, Lehzen and Lady Flora followed us also."Victoria's diary, 11 November 1834, quoted in Longford, p. 43 While two passing gentlemen cut the horses free, the ladies, and Dash, took shelter behind a wall.Woodham-Smith, p. 96 Dash remained with Victoria after her accession as queen in 1837. Following her [[Coronation of the British monarch|coronation]] on 28 June 1838, Victoria returned to [[Buckingham Palace]] and ran up to her rooms to give Dash his usual bath.Longford, p. 83; Strachey, p. 73 Dash died at the end of 1840, and was buried at [[Adelaide Cottage]] in Windsor Home Park. A marble effigy was erected over the grave, bearing the inscription: {| cellspacing="0" {{quotation |
Here lies
DASH
The favourite spaniel of Her Majesty Queen Victoria
In his 10th year
His attachment was without selfishness
His playfulness without malice
His fidelity without deceit
READER
If you would be beloved and die regretted
Profit by the example of
DASH
}} |} ==See also== [[File:Her Majesty's Favourite Pets.jpg|thumb|right|Dash (left) with Lory (parrot), Nero (greyhound) and Hector (Scottish deerhound) by [[Edwin Henry Landseer]], 1838]] *[[Caesar (dog)]], terrier owned by [[King Edward VII]] *[[Queen Victoria's pets]] *[[Susan (dog)]], progenitor of the [[Queen Elizabeth's corgis|long line of Pembroke Corgis]] owned by [[Queen Elizabeth II]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== *[[Elizabeth Pakenham, Countess of Longford|Longford, Elizabeth]] (1964) ''Victoria R.I.'', London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, {{ISBN|0-297-17001-5}} *[[Colin Matthew|Matthew, H. C. G.]]; Reynolds, K.D. (2004) [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36652 "Victoria (1819–1901)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, subscription required for online edition {{doi|10.1093/ref:odnb/36652}} *[[Lytton Strachey|Strachey, Lytton]] (1921) ''Queen Victoria'', London: Chatto and Windus *[[Cecil Woodham-Smith|Woodham-Smith, Cecil]] (1972) ''Queen Victoria: Her Life and Times 1819–1861'', London: Hamish Hamilton, {{ISBN|0-241-02200-2}} {{Queen Victoria}} [[Category:Individual dogs in politics]] [[Category:Queen Victoria]] [[Category:1830 animal births]] [[Category:1840 animal deaths]] [[Category:Pets of the British Royal Family]] [[Category:Dogs in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Individual animals in the United Kingdom]]

'''Death trajectory''' refers to the pattern<ref>{{cite web|title=Patterns of Functional Decline at the End of Life|url=https://palliative.stanford.edu/overview-of-palliative-care/patterns-of-functional-decline-at-the-end-of-life/|website=Stanford School of Medicine|publisher=Stanford Medicine|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref> of [[Death|dying]] when a patient is given a projected death date with limited or no medical recourse for the remaining existence of the individual's life.<ref name=one>{{cite book | title=Death & Dying, Life & Living, Seventh Edition | publisher=Cengage Learning | author=Corr & Corr | year=2012 | isbn=978-1111840617}}</ref> The death trajectory is dependent on the cause of death, whether it is sudden death, [[chronic condition|chronic illness]], or the steady decline in health due to [[senescence]] (aging).<ref name="two">{{cite web|url=http://www.hawaii.edu/aging/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Saying-Goodbye.pdf|title=Preparing to say Good-Bye|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=University of Hawaii|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> Death trajectory is analyzed in two separate aspects: duration and shape. Duration refers to the period of time a patient has to live, which can be anywhere from imminent death to several months.<ref name=one /> Shape refers to how that duration is then graphed. In other words, the shape is "the course of dying, its predictability, and whether death is expected or unexpected".<ref name=one />
[[File:Sudden Death graph.png|thumb|Illustration of the premature death trajectory. There is a sharp decline in human function in a short period of time.|205x205px]] Dying trajectories were first studied in the 1960s by two researchers, [[Barney Glaser]] and [[Anselm Strauss]], in an attempt to understand the end of human life from different ailments, including cancer.<ref name="six">{{cite web |url=http://fammed.washington.edu/palliativecare/requirements/resources/TrajectoryOfDying.htm |title=Trajectory of Dying |publisher=University of Washington |accessdate=20 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150306060758/http://www.fammed.washington.edu/palliativecare/requirements/resources/TrajectoryOfDying.htm |archivedate=6 March 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Sudden death trajectory== Sudden or premature death occurs when the death of an individual is not perceived to be imminent. In a sudden death trajectory, an otherwise healthy and high-functioning individual will suddenly and [[unnatural death|unexpectedly die]] without any observable indications of oncoming demise. People are at a high or normal level of functioning until the moment of death occurs. These types of deaths include fatal accidents and inconspicuous health issues like [[myocardial infarction]] or severe stroke. Deaths that align with a sudden death trajectory may happen over the course of a few days or in a matter of seconds.
==Chronic malady trajectory== [[File:Length of Dying Process.png|thumb|A chronic malady trajectory showing an overall decline in health with intermittent rises and falls in human function.|left|187x187px]]The chronic malady trajectory occurs with types of death caused by [[autoimmune disease]]s such as [[HIV]] or other incurable illnesses. This process of death is characterized by an overall decline in health accompanied by [[Recrudescence|acute crises]] and intermittent [[Cure#Remission|recoveries]].<ref name="two" /> The chronic malady trajectory projects emotional stress or turmoil;<ref name=one /> the patient may eventually become [[Fatigue (medical)#Chronic fatigue|mentally]] and [[emotional exhaustion|emotionally exhausted]].
==Natural death trajectory== [[File:Steady decline.png|thumb|A typical natural death trajectory chronicling a long, steady decline in health over time.]] A natural death trajectory is typically a long, steady decline due to [[aging-associated diseases|old age]].<ref>Dolejs, Josef; Marešová, Petra. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5268335/ "Onset of mortality increase with age and age trajectories of mortality from all diseases in the four Nordic countries"], ''[[National Center for Biotechnology Information]]''</ref> In these cases, the death trajectory is based on how the mind and body degenerate, including the speed of organ failure. In these cases, it is much easier to anticipate a person's death.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gerstorf|first1=Denis|last2=Ram|first2=Nilam|last3=Lindenberger|first3=Ulman|last4=Smith|first4=Jacqui|title=Age and time-to-death trajectories of change in indicators of cognitive, sensory, physical, health, social, and self-related functions|journal=Developmental Psychology|date=2013|volume=49|issue=10|pages=1805–1821|doi=10.1037/a0031340|pmid=23356526|hdl=11858/00-001M-0000-0024-EC54-F}}</ref>
==Medical care== When someone has an estimated death date and a death trajectory, the patient's caregivers generally cease curative care and proceed to provide [[palliative care|palliative]] or comfort care.<ref name=one /> Curative care refers to situations where the patient still feels it is possible to use current medical care to recover or become stable enough to carry on with life. Comfort care, or [[Hospice|hospice care]], is reserved for patients who acknowledge they will not be able to recover.
==See also== * [[Aging-associated diseases]] * [[Palliative care]]
==References== <references />
