'''USS ''Gudgeon'' (SS-211)''', a [[Tambor class submarine|''Tambor'']]-class [[submarine]], was the first ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for the [[gudgeon (fish)|gudgeon]].
==Pre-war== Her keel was laid down by the [[Mare Island Navy Yard]]. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 25 January 1941, sponsored by Mrs. Annie B. Pye, wife of Vice Admiral [[William S. Pye]], Commander Battleships, Battle Force and Commander Battle Force. The boat was [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 21 April 1941 with Lieutenant Commander [[List of military figures by nickname|Elton W. "Joe" Grenfell]] in command. Her construction cost $6 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Submarine Launched from Mare Island|publisher=San Bernardino County Sun|date=26 Jan 1941|page=1}}</ref>
After [[shakedown cruise|shakedown]] along the [[California]] coast, ''Gudgeon'' sailed north on 28 August, heading for [[Alaska]] via [[Seattle, Washington]]. On her northern jaunt the new submarine inspected [[Sitka, Alaska|Sitka]], [[Kodiak, Alaska|Kodiak]], and [[Dutch Harbor]] for suitability as naval bases. Continuing to [[Hawaii]], she moored at the [[Pearl Harbor Naval Base|Pearl Harbor]] [[submarine base]] on 10 October 1941. Training exercises and local operations filled ''Gudgeon''’s time for the next two months. During the Japanese [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] on 7 December she was at [[Lahaina Roads]] on special exercises, but returned to base immediately.
==World War II== ===First war patrol===
On 11 December, ''Gudgeon'' (commanded by [[Elton W. Grenfell|Elton W. "Joe" Grenfell]]) departed [[Pearl Harbor Naval Base|Pearl Harbor]] on the first American submarine war patrol of [[World War II]]. Her commanding officer was provided with explicit written orders to carry out [[unrestricted submarine warfare]].<ref>The orders were probably designed to prevent the Japanese from hanging him as a pirate, under the belief Article 22 of the [[London Naval Treaty]] prohibited his actions. See Holwitt, Joel I. ''"Execute Against Japan"'', Ph.D. dissertation, Ohio State University, 2005, p.295 & ''passim''.</ref> ''Gudgeon'' made her first contact on a target in Japanese Home Waters 31 December.<ref>Blair, Clay, Jr. ''Silent Victory'' (New York: Bantam, 1976), pp.107 & 110.</ref> When she returned 50 days later,<ref>Blair, p.901.</ref> ''Gudgeon'' had contributed two more impressive "firsts" to the Pacific submarine fleet. She was the first American submarine to patrol along the Japanese coast itself, as her area took her off [[Kyūshū]] in the home islands. On 27 January 1942, ''en route'' home, ''Gudgeon'' became the first [[United States Navy]] submarine to sink an enemy warship in [[World War II]]. ''Gudgeon'' fired three torpedoes, and [[Japanese submarine I-73|''I-73'']]<ref>http://www.combinedfleet.com/I-73.htm</ref> was destroyed; though ''Gudgeon'' claimed only damage, the loss was confirmed by [[Station HYPO|HYPO]].<ref>Blair, p.118, names her ''I-173''.</ref>
===Second and third patrols===
On her second war patrol, 22 February to 15 April 1942, ''Gudgeon'' scored two kills, first an unknown freighter on 26 March (not identified or confirmed by [[Joint Army–Navy Assessment Committee|JANAC]]), then sinking the 6526-ton ''Nissho Maru'' on 27 March in the [[East China Sea]] southeast of [[Geumodo Island|Kumun Island]].
She then checked into dry-dock for overhaul, but undocked three weeks early and readied for sea in a remarkable 40 hours to participate in the momentous [[Battle of Midway]].
Departing Pearl Harbor on 18 May, ''Gudgeon'' took station off [[Midway Atoll]] as part of the submarine screen which encircled the two giant fleets clashing there. ''Gudgeon'' was prevented from offensive action by the confusion of battle, the possibility of mistaken identity, and poor staff work by Admiral [[Robert Henry English|Robert English]], <small>[[COMSUBPAC]]</small>.<ref>Blair, ''Silent Victory'' (Bantam, 1976), pp.239 and 241</ref> She returned to Pearl Harbor on 14 June.
===Fourth patrol===
Departing for her fourth patrol 11 July, ''Gudgeon'' sank the 4853-ton transport ''Naniwa Maru'' in a night submerged attack off [[Chuuk Lagoon|Truk]] on 3 August, her only kill of the patrol. In her other attack of the fourth patrol USS Gudgeon carried out an aggressive attack on a four-ship convoy 17 August, torpedoing and damaging the Japanese tankers ''Shinkoku Maru'' (10020 BRT) and ''Nichiei Maru'' (10020 BRT) northwest of Truk before the patrol ended at [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]], [[Australia]], on 2 September.
===Fifth and sixth patrols===
Now a part of the Southwestern Pacific submarine forces, ''Gudgeon'' sank the 6783-ton ''Choko Maru'' west-northwest of Rabaul on 21 October during her fifth war patrol, 8 October to 1 December, and carried out a daring attack on a seven ship convoy on 11 November, torpedoing several ships but sinking none.
The submarine's sixth war patrol, from 27 December 1942 to 18 February 1943, was unsuccessful in terms of ships sunk, but she carried out two special missions. On 14 January 1943 ''Gudgeon'' successfully landed six men on [[Catmon Point]], [[Negros Island]], [[Western Visayas]], [[Philippines]], to carry out the vital guerrilla resistance movement there. Returning from her patrol area, ''Gudgeon'' was diverted to [[Timor Island]] on 9 February, and the following day rescued 28 men—Australian, English, Portuguese, and Filipino—for passage to [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]].
===Seventh and eighth patrols===
''Gudgeon''{{'}}s seventh war patrol, from 13 March into April 1943, netted her two more Japanese ships before she ran out of torpedoes and had to return to [[Australia]]. On 22 March she sank the 5434-ton transport ''Meigen Maru'' as well as seriously damaging two other ships in the Java Sea convoy some 30 miles north of [[Surabaya]], [[Java (island)|Java]], [[Netherlands East Indies]]. Five days later ''Gudgeon'' took on 9987-ton tanker [[Japanese oiler Tōhō Maru (1936)|''Tōhō Maru'']] in a night surface attack in the [[Makassar Strait]] punctuated by bursts of gunfire as the Japanese ships spotted and fired on the submarine. It took five torpedoes to sink ''Tōhō Maru'', and most of ''Gudgeon'''s crew enjoyed the rare treat of watching her slide into the depths. Another attack later the same day damaged the 1192-ton tanker ''Kyoei Maru''.
On her eighth war patrol, conducted as she sailed from [[Australia]] to Pearl Harbor on 15 April to 25 May 1943, ''Gudgeon'' chalked up three more kills. Her first came 28 April as she sank ''[[Kamakura Maru]]'', a former ocean liner, southwest of [[Pucio Point]], [[Panay]] (now Poblacion, Libertad, Antique), Philippines. The 17,526-ton transport was the largest Japanese transport, and one of the largest enemy ships sunk by an American submarine. Special operations interrupted ''Gudgeon'''s patrol as she landed six trained guerrilla fighters and three tons of equipment for the guerrilla movement on Panay on 30 April.
After sinking the 500-ton trawler ''Naku Maru'' with her deck guns west of Panay 4 May, ''Gudgeon'' battle-surfaced again that same day and left a coastal steamer burning and settling. Eight days later, on 12 May, she torpedoed and sank the 5861-ton freighter ''Sumatra Maru'' off [[Bulusan]], [[Luzon]], Philippines. Returning to Pearl Harbor, the veteran submarine was sent to [[San Francisco, California]], for badly needed overhaul, her first since commissioning two years earlier.
===Ninth and tenth patrols===
A refreshed sub and crew departed Pearl Harbor for their ninth war patrol 1 September 1943 in the [[Mariana Islands]] area. Before returning to [[Midway Island]] on 6 October with all [[torpedo]]es expended, ''Gudgeon'' had sunk the 3158-ton ''Taian Maru'', torpedoed and damaged the 3266-ton auxiliary gunboat ''Santo Maru'' north of [[Saipan]], as well as seriously damaging several other ships.
Heading along the [[China]] coast for her tenth war patrol, form 31 October to 11 December, ''Gudgeon'' chalked up two more marus. Early in the morning of 23 November she spotted a convoy of four ships in the East China Sea some 70 miles north of [[Zhoushan Island|Shusan Island]] and closed for attack. ''Gudgeon'' fired a spread of six torpedoes with gratifying results. The 870-ton [[Japanese frigate Wakamiya|frigate ''Wakamiya'']],<ref>http://www.combinedfleet.com/Wakamiya_t.htm</ref> hit by one torpedo, broke in two, sinking almost immediately. The two tankers in the convoy, the 5106-ton ''Ichiyo Maru'' and the 8469-ton ''Goyo Maru'', were also hit but managed to escape. ''Gudgeon'' closed in to finish off the 6783-ton troop transport ''Nekka Maru''.
===Eleventh patrol===
''Gudgeon'''s 11th war patrol saw a few successful sinkings of Japanese vessels, the first on 11 February. Before this sinking the submarine had a spell of bad luck where, on 2 February 1944, she had sighted a damaged [[aircraft carrier]] with two escorts. ''Gudgeon'' had closed for attack, but the escorts spotted her and attacked. A down-the-throat shot with four torpedoes temporarily discouraged the destroyers and allowed ''Gudgeon'' to seek deep water and safety, but when she surfaced the Japanese men-of-war were gone. Later in the same patrol ''Gudgeon'' was forced to try another down-the-throat shot at an enemy escort, but no hits. Success came only on 11 February. This date saw her torpedoing and sinking the already damaged (by [[Chinese military|Chinese]] air attack) 3091-ton [[merchant]] ''Satsuma Maru'' off [[Wenchow]], China. On 17 February ''Gudgeon'' sank a Japanese sampan with gunfire in the East China Sea, another sampan being damaged in the attack. She returned to Pearl Harbor on 5 March 1944.
===Twelfth path and loss===
''Gudgeon'' sailed for her 12th war patrol on 4 April 1944. The [[submarine]] stopped off for fuel at [[Johnston Island]] on 7 April, and was never seen or heard from again. On 7 June 1944, ''Gudgeon'' was officially declared overdue and presumed lost. Uboat.net claims ''Gudgeon'' was sunk 18 April 1944 at a known location by the Japanese southeast of [[Iwo Jima]].<ref>http://uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/2923.html</ref> Some sources say the submarine was more likely to have sunk by attack near the [[Maug Islands]].
For more detailed and original information about ''Gudgeon''{{'}}s likely sinking on 18 April 1944, see ''Find 'Em Chase 'Em Sink 'Em: The Mysterious Loss of the WW II Submarine USS Gudgeon'' and other "Ostlund" references below.
===Tally and honors=== During her three-year career, ''Gudgeon'' scored 14 confirmed kills of a total of well over 71,372 tons sunk, placing her 15th on the [[List of most successful American submarines in World War II|honor roll of American submarines]].
For her first seven war patrols ''Gudgeon'' received the [[Presidential Unit Citation (US)|Presidential Unit Citation]]. She earned 11 [[battle star]]s for [[World War II]] service.

page.title: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum shooting

revision.text:
{{Infobox civilian attack |title=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum shooting |image = United States Holocaust Memorial Museum after the shooting.jpeg |caption = The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum on the day after the shooting. |location = [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] |target = |date = {{start date|2009|6|10}} |time = 12:50 [[12-hour clock|p.m.]]<ref name=wapothursday/> |timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |type =Shooting, hate crime |fatalities = 1<ref name=CNN/> |injuries = 2 (including the perpetrator)<ref name=wjla/><ref name='Post' /> |perp = [[James von Brunn|James Wenneker von Brunn]]<ref name=CNN/> |weapons = [[.22 caliber rifle]]<ref name=yahoo/> |motive = Hate crime }} {{Antisemitism}} <!--No need for bold title in lead section, see [[WP:BOLDAVOID]]--> At about 12:50 p.m. on June 10, 2009, 88-year-old [[white supremacist]] [[James von Brunn|James Wenneker von Brunn]] entered the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] with a rifle and fatally shot Museum Special Police Officer Stephen Tyrone Johns. Other security guards returned fire, wounding von Brunn, who was apprehended.<ref name=wapothursday/><ref name=wjla>{{cite news|url=http://www.wjla.com/news/stories/0609/630674.html|title=Guard Slain in Museum Shootout ID'd; Gunman Hospitalized|date=2009-06-10|publisher=[[WJLA-TV]]|accessdate=2009-06-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090613040641/http://www.wjla.com/news/stories/0609/630674.html|archivedate=2009-06-13|df=}}</ref><ref name=Post>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/10/AR2009061001768.html?hpid=topnews|title=2 People Shot at U.S. Holocaust Museum|last=Wilgoren|first=Debbi|author2=Branigin, William |date=2009-06-10|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref><ref name="WilberDeath">Del Quentin Wilber, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/06/AR2010010604095_pf.html Von Brunn, white supremacist Holocaust museum shooter, dies], ''Washington Post'' (January 7, 2010), B01.</ref>
Von Brunn was charged in federal court on June 11, 2009, with [[first-degree murder]] and firearms violations.<ref name=CriminalCharges>{{cite news |url=http://news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/crim/us-von-brunn61109cmp.html|title=Criminal Complaint (U.S v. James Wenneker von Brunn)|date=2009-06-11|publisher=[[FindLaw]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> On July 29, 2009, von Brunn was [[Indictment|indicted]] by a [[federal grand jury]] on seven counts, including four which made him eligible for the [[Capital punishment in the United States|death penalty]]; the charges included [[Hate crime laws in the United States|hate crime]] counts.<ref name=indictment>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/07/29/ST2009072902450.html|title=Holocaust Museum Shooter Indicted on First-Degree Murder|last=Wilber|first=Del Quentin|date=2009-07-29|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref><ref name=federalbureau>{{cite press release|url=https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/washingtondc/press-releases/2009/wfo072909.htm|title=James Von Brunn Indicted for Murder of Special Police Officer Stephen Johns and Hate Crimes Charges for Attack on the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|date=2009-07-29|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> In September 2009, a judge ordered von Brunn to undergo a [[Competency evaluation (law)|competency evaluation]] to determine whether or not he could stand trial.<ref name=evaluation>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/29/us/29brfs-SHOOTINGSUSP_BRF.html|title=North Carolina: Shooting Defendant Is Transferred |date=2009-09-28|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The New York Times|pages=A23|accessdate=2009-09-29}}</ref> On January 6, 2010, von Brunn died of natural causes while awaiting trial.<ref name=pilkington>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jan/07/holocaust-museum-shooting-suspect-dies | title=Holocaust museum shooting suspect dies | last=Pilkington | first=Ed | date=January 7, 2010 | work=[[The Guardian]] | publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]] | accessdate=January 7, 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
Von Brunn was a [[White supremacy|white supremacist]] and [[Holocaust denial|Holocaust denier]]. He had previously been convicted of entering a [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] building with various weapons in 1981 while trying to place the members of the [[Federal Reserve Board of Governors]], who he considered to be treasonous, under citizen's arrest.<ref name="WilberDeath"/><ref name="nytimes1981">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/us/suspect-is-seized-in-capital-in-threat-at-federal-reserve.html|title=Suspect is seized in Capital in threat at Federal Reserve|date=1981-12-08|agency=[[United Press International]]|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Background== The Holocaust Museum has been a target for [[antisemitism|antisemites]] and [[Holocaust denial|Holocaust deniers]] since it was established in 1993. In 2002, federal prosecutors said two [[2002 white supremacist terror plot|white supremacists plotted]] to blow up the museum with a [[ANFO|fertilizer bomb]], as was used to [[Oklahoma City bombing|blow up a federal building]] in [[Oklahoma]] in 1995.<ref name=2002plot/>
==Shooting== {{seealso|James von Brunn}} At about 12:49 p.m., 88-year-old James von Brunn<ref name=cbsnews>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/06/10/national/main5078816.shtml|title=Shooting Suspect Wrote Of "Holocaust Hoax"|last=Condon|first=Stephanie|date=2009-06-10|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=2009-06-12}}</ref><ref name=times>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article6473316.ece|title=White supremacist James W Von Brunn opens fire at Holocaust museum|date=2009-06-10|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=2009-06-10 |location=London |first=Tim |last=Reid}}</ref><ref name=NPR>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105207253|title=Gunman Shoots, Kills Guard At Holocaust Museum|date=2009-06-10|work=[[National Public Radio]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> drove his car to the [[14th Street Northwest and Southwest (Washington, D.C.)|14th Street]] entrance of the museum.<ref name=wapothursday>{{cite news |first=Ashley |last=Halsey III |author2=Paul Duggan |title='Was He Capable of This? Yes.' |date=2009-06-11 |url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/11/AR2009061101086.html |work=Washington Post |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref><ref name=CriminalCharges /> Von Brunn entered the museum when Museum Special Police Officer Stephen Tyrone Johns opened the door for him.<ref name=nydaily>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/us_world/2009/06/11/2009-06-11_holocaust_museum_guard_.html|title='Obama created by Jews': Holocaust Museum shooting suspect James von Brunn's chilling racist note|author=Sisk, Richard|author2=Schapiro, Richard |date=2009-06-11|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> Authorities said he raised a [[.22-caliber rifle]]<ref name=yahoo>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090610/ap_on_re_us/us_holocaust_museum_shooting|title=Elderly gunman kills guard at Holocaust Museum|last=Syeed|first=Nafeesa|author2=Epso, David |date=2009-06-10|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=2009-06-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090613020706/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090610/ap_on_re_us/us_holocaust_museum_shooting |archivedate=2009-06-13}}</ref> and shot Special Police Officer Johns,<ref name=wjla/><ref name=Post/> who later died of his injuries at the [[George Washington University|George Washington University Hospital]].<ref name=CNN/> Two other Special Police Officers stationed with Officer Johns, Harry Weeks and Jason "Mac" McCuiston, returned fire, wounding von Brunn with a shot to the face.<ref name=guards>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/livecoverage/2009/06/guard_who_shot_von_brunn_is_re.html?hpid=topnews|title=Guards Who Stopped Von Brunn Were Retired Cop, Ex-Marine|date=2009-06-12|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-06-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> According to police officers at the scene, a third person was injured by broken glass but refused treatment at the hospital.<ref name=CNN>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/06/10/museum.shooting/index.html|title=Shooting reported at Holocaust Museum in Washington|date=2009-06-10|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref>
===Immediate aftermath=== [[File:Stephen Tyrone Johns.JPG|thumb|left|95px|A sign honoring Stephen Tyrone Johns, the Special Police Officer shot and killed during the shooting, located in the museum's lobby.]] ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that "if it weren't for the quick response of the private guards on duty, more people could have been killed or wounded." [[List of mayors of Washington, D.C.|Mayor]] [[Adrian Fenty]] stated that the officers' efforts "to bring this gunman down so quickly ... saved the lives of countless people... This could have been much, much worse."<ref name=fenty>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/11/AR2009061103848_pf.html|title=Fast Action By Guards Saved Lives, Officials Say|last=Davenport|first=Christian|date=2009-06-12|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-06-12}}</ref> Inside, the museum was crowded with visiting schoolchildren.<ref name=wjla/> Museum officials said that "the entire incident unfolded in approximately two minutes."<ref name=foxnews>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/06/10/gunman-opens-inside-holocaust-museum-kills-security-guard/|title=Gunman Opens Fire Inside Holocaust Museum, Kills Security Guard|date=June 10, 2009|publisher=Fox News|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527083145/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/06/10/gunman-opens-inside-holocaust-museum-kills-security-guard/|archivedate=May 27, 2010|df=}}</ref>
After the shooting, the nearby [[U.S. Department of Agriculture Administration Building]], [[Bureau of Engraving and Printing]], and the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]]'s [[Sidney Yates Building|Sidney R. Yates Federal Building]] were closed.<ref name=kpcc>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/blogs/kitty-felde/2009/06/11/bad-day-museum/|title=A Bad Day at the Museum|last=Felde|first=Kitty|date=June 11, 2009|publisher=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603235527/http://www.scpr.org/blogs/kitty-felde/2009/06/11/bad-day-museum/|archivedate=June 3, 2011|df=}}</ref> Portions of 14th Street and [[Independence Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Independence Avenue]] in the [[Southwest, Washington, D.C.|Southwest]] [[Quadrants of Washington, D.C.|quadrant]] were closed until later in the night.<ref name=closure>{{cite news|title=Street Closures Affiliated with Holocaust Museum Shooting|url=http://dcist.com/2009/06/street_closures_affiliated_with_hol.php|last=Mathis|first=Sommer|date=2009-06-10|publisher=[[Gothamist|DCist]]|accessdate=2009-06-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614234429/http://dcist.com/2009/06/street_closures_affiliated_with_hol.php|archivedate=2009-06-14|df=}}</ref> The car driven by von Brunn was found [[Double parking|double parked]] in front of the museum and tested for explosives.<ref name='APGuard-dies'>{{cite news |title=Guard dies after Holocaust museum shooting |date=2009-06-11 |publisher=MSNBC |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31208188/ |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref>
Police said they found a notebook on von Brunn that contained a list of District locations, including the [[Washington National Cathedral]]; they dispatched [[Bomb disposal|bomb squads]] to at least 10 sites.<ref name=baltimore>{{cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/nation/bal-te.shooting11jun11,0,2162870.story|title=Maryland man held in Holocaust museum attack|author=Meyer, Josh|author3=Oliphant, James|author2=Zajaz, Andrew |date=2009-06-11|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The notebook also contained this passage, signed by von Brunn: "You want my weapons—this is how you'll get them. [[The Holocaust]] is a lie. [[Barack Obama|Obama]] was created by [[Jew]]s. Obama does what his Jew owners tell him to do. Jews captured America's money. Jews control the mass media. The [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|1st Amendment]] is abrogated henceforth."<ref name=CriminalCharges />
The FBI and Washington, D.C. police chief [[Cathy L. Lanier]] said that it appeared von Brunn was acting alone at the time of the shooting, and the FBI said it had no knowledge of any threat against the museum.<ref name=WTOP>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtopnews.com/?nid=25&sid=1693510|title=Gunman, guards exchange fire in D.C. Museum |date=2009-06-10|publisher=[[WTOP-FM]]|accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref><ref name='FBIstatement'>{{cite press release|url=https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/washingtondc/press-releases/2009/wfo061009-1.htm|title=Statement Regarding Shooting at United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C. |date=June 10, 2009|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]}}</ref> The museum's director of security said they receive threats, but "nothing this significant recently".<ref name=2002plot>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/wire/sns-ap-us-holocaust-museum,1,85556.story|title=Holocaust Museum has attracted anti-Semitism, hatred from its inception|author=Frommer, Frederic J.|date=2002-07-26|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2009-06-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615002329/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/wire/sns-ap-us-holocaust-museum,1,85556.story |archivedate=2009-06-15}}</ref>
===Possible motives=== Several news agencies have noted the timing of the June 10 shooting; it came shortly after Obama's June 5 visit to and speech at the [[Buchenwald concentration camp]],<ref name=allheadlinenews>{{cite news|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7015471394|title=Less Than A Week After Obama's Buchenwald Visit, House Passes Resolution Condemning Holocaust Shooting|last=Alingod|first=Kris|date=2009-06-12|publisher=All Headline News|accessdate=2009-06-17}}{{dead link|date=June 2014}}</ref> and that "President Obama’s recent visit to the Buchenwald Concentration Camp, in [[Germany]], may have set off the shooter."<ref name=scoop>{{cite news|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/HL0906/S00175.htm|title=Shooting in the Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC|last=Lawn|first=Connie|date=2009-06-17|publisher=[[Scoop (news website)|Scoop]]|accessdate=2009-06-17}}</ref>
On his website, von Brunn stated that his conviction in the 1980s was by "a [[Negro]] jury, Jew/Negro [[Attorney at law (United States)|attorneys]]" and that he was "sentenced to prison for eleven years by a Jew judge." A [[Court of Appeals]] denied his appeal.<ref name=times/>
==Victim== '''Special Police Officer Stephen Tyrone Johns''' (October 4, 1969 – June 10, 2009), a [[Temple Hills, Maryland]] native, was an employee of [[Wackenhut]] who was, at the time of the shooting, stationed at the door of the museum when von Brunn entered with a .22 caliber long rifle and shot him. He later died at the George Washington University Hospital. His funeral was held on June 19, 2009 at Ebenezer AME Church in Fort Washington, Maryland, with 2,000 attendees,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/19/AR2009061900532.html|title=Grieving for 'Another Victim of an Evil ... Mentality'|author=Keith L. Alexander and Hamil R. Harris|work=Washington Post|date=June 20, 2009}}</ref> and he was subsequently interred. Johns was married to Zakiah Johns (since May 2008) with a son, Stephen Johns, Jr., and two stepsons, Jeffrey Pollard and Tysean Lawson-Bey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSob=c&GSvcid=44739&GRid=38161056&|title=Stephen Tyrone Johns (1970–2009)|publisher=[[Find a Grave]]}}</ref> The [[American Jewish Committee]] established a memorial fund for the family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.jta.org/2009/06/11/news-opinion/the-telegraph/ajc-sets-up-fund-for-family-of-officer-johns|title=AJC sets up fund for family of Officer Johns |author=Eric Fingerhut|agency=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|date=June 11, 2009}}</ref>
==Perpetrator== {{Main|James von Brunn}} James W. von Brunn died in prison while awaiting trial on January 6, 2010.<ref name="WilberDeath"/> He was in poor health and suffered from congestive heart failure and sepsis.<ref name="WilberDeath"/>
Following his death, the ''Washington Post'' notes: "His guilt was never in serious doubt -- the shooting was witnessed by dozens of people, it was captured on surveillance video and the assailant was carted away in an ambulance -- but some had hoped to glean some insights into von Brunn's psyche during the court process. Many, including Johns's relatives, remain shocked that anyone could be filled with so much hatred that he would shoot a helpful security guard at a museum that serves as a memorial to the slaughter of millions of people."<ref name="WilberDeath"/>
==Witnesses and events at the museum== Present at the museum during the shooting was former [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[William Cohen]], awaiting his wife [[Janet Langhart]]; the two were at the museum for the premiere of Langhart's one-act play, ''[[Anne and Emmett]]''. The play imagines a conversation between two teenagers, [[Nazi]] victim [[Anne Frank]] and [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow]] victim [[Emmett Till]]. Her play was to be presented in honor of the eightieth anniversary of Anne Frank's birth.<ref name=cohen>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/religion/post/2009/06/67959221/1|author=Grossman, Cathy Lynn|title=Tragedy at the Holocaust museum and giving voice to the slain|date=2009-06-10|publisher=''USA Today''|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
==Reaction== [[Image:Holocaust Museum flag at half-staff.jpg|thumb|upright|The day after the shooting, the Holocaust Museum's flag flew at half-staff in memory of the murdered guard, Stephen Tyrone Johns.]] The [[Embassy of Israel in Washington, D.C.|Israeli embassy in Washington]] condemned the attack. [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said, "This outrageous act reminds us that we must remain vigilant against anti-Semitism and prejudice in all its forms."<ref name=whitehouse>{{cite news|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/2009/06/10/holocaust-museum-shooting|title=On the Holocaust Museum Shooting|date=2009-06-10|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]}}</ref><ref name=bbcnews>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8094076.stm|title=US Holocaust museum guard killed|date=June 11, 2009|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], [[Anti-Defamation League]], and FBI stated they had been monitoring von Brunn's Internet postings, but were unable to take action because his comments had not crossed the line from [[Freedom of speech in the United States|free speech]] into illegal threats or incitement.<ref name=latimesmotive>{{cite news|title=Investigators in Holocaust museum shooting continue to look for clues|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-holocaust-shooting12-2009jun12,0,7406829.story|last=Meyer|first=Josh|date=June 12, 2009|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref name=poverty>{{cite news|title=Southern Poverty Law Center Had Monitored Museum Shooting Suspect|url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/southern_poverty_law_center_had_monitored_holocaust_shooting_suspect/|last=Weiss|first=Debra Cassens|date=June 11, 2009|magazine=ABA Journal}}</ref>
On June 11, 2009, the [[Jewish Community Relations Council]] of Greater Washington and the [[InterFaith Conference of Metropolitan Washington]] led a prayer [[vigil]] which took place in front of the museum to honor Stephen Johns, the slain officer.<ref name=vigil>{{cite news|title=Holocaust Museum Shooting Vigil Planned for 2 p.m.|url=http://dcist.com/2009/06/holocaust_vigil_planned_for_2_pm.php|last=Mathis|first=Sommer|date=June 11, 2009|publisher=DCist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614092511/http://dcist.com/2009/06/holocaust_vigil_planned_for_2_pm.php|archivedate=June 14, 2009|df=}}</ref> Approximately 100 people attended the event, including officials from the Israeli and [[Embassy of Germany in Washington, D.C.|German embassies]].<ref name=washtimes>{{cite news|title=Tourists shocked, but carrying on|url=http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/12/tourists-shocked-but-try-to-carry-on/|last=Giaimo|first=Melissa|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=June 12, 2009}}</ref> The [[Council on American-Islamic Relations]] condemned the attack as well.<ref name="baltimore"/> When the museum reopened on June 12, 2009, Director Sara Bloomfield said attendance was normal or even higher than usual. Many visitors said their attendance was a statement against hate and intolerance. A 17-year-old girl who was in the museum the day of the shooting stated, "It's important to come back, because if you don't, they win. It's a form of terrorism."<ref name=reopening>{{cite news|title=Stepping Up to Defy Intolerance|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/06/11/ST2009061101157.html?sid=ST2009061101157|last=Davenport|first=Christian|date=June 11, 2009|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
On the [[White nationalism|white nationalist]] Internet forum [[Stormfront (website)|Stormfront]], some users criticized von Brunn's actions, saying they hurt the forum's cause. Others supported him in threads that were later removed.<ref name=editor>{{cite news|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003982248|title=What the Media Missed in Museum Shooting: Far-Right Reaction|last=Mitchell|first=Greg|date=June 10, 2009|magazine=[[Editor & Publisher]]|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617050552/http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003982248|archivedate=June 17, 2009|df=}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''`Abd ar-Rahman ibn Muhammad''' (died 16 June 1825) was the Emir of [[Harar]] (1821 - 1825).
On the death of his brother, Emir [[Ahmad II ibn Muhammad]], `Abd ar-Rahman and his other brother [[`Abd al-Karim ibn Muhammad|`Abd al-Karim]] quarreled over who would succeed, and `Abd ar-Rahman gained the throne first with the help of the [[Babille Oromo]] who dwelled to the east of Harar. However, while returning from an unsuccessful campaign to extract tribute from the [[Ala Oromo]] in 1825, he was betrayed to these people and `Abd al-Karim made himself Emir. Abd al-Rahman appealed for help from his Babille allies, who helped him resist his deposition. In the end, `Abd ar-Rahman was deposed and forty villages are listed as having been destroyed by the Oromo to the north, west and south of harar, as well as in Babille country during this civil war.<ref name=Caulk-377>R. A. Caulk, "Harar Town and Its Neighbours in the Nineteenth Century", ''Journal of African History'', 18 (1977), p. 377</ref>
According to [[Richard F. Burton]], `Abd al-Karim had recruited 60 or 70 Arab matchlockmen, under one Haydar Assal the Auliki, to fight against the Oromo. The mercenaries ran out of ammunition, and losing twenty of their number retired to Harar. The Oromo captured Abd al-Karim and Abd Ar-Rahman, seized the throne and with the aid of the inhabitants started to murder the Arab mercenaries. The mercenaries, however, defended themselves and would have restored Abd al-Rahman as Emir, had Abd ar-Rahman not declined their offer; the Arab mercenaries then drew their pay and marched off to [[Zeila]].<ref>Richard Burton, ''First Footsteps in East Africa'', 1856; edited with an introduction and additional chapters by Gordon Waterfield (New York: Praeger, 1966), p. 189, note</ref> R.A. Caulk explains that this was a garbled version of the fraternal battle for the throne.<ref name=Caulk-377/>
One source states that he had one daughter, Guisti Fatima, who married his eventual successor [[Abu Bakr II ibn `Abd al-Munan]].<ref>[http://www.royalark.net/Ethiopia/harrar.htm Ethiopia: Adal & Harar], Royal Ark genealogies (accessed 6 April 2009)</ref>
